content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". Congress finds that diabetes is a major public health threat in the US, with millions affected and increasing prevalence. Diabetes self-management training is crucial for patients to learn necessary skills and overcome barriers. The prevalence of diabetes has tripled in the last 30 years, with 2,200 new diagnoses daily. Diabetes self-management training, provided by certified educators, helps patients develop skills to manage their condition and prevent complications. Diabetes self-management training, offered by certified educators, assists individuals in developing skills to manage their condition and prevent complications. Research has shown that lifestyle changes can significantly reduce the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, particularly in individuals aged 60 and older. Participants at increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes reduced their risk by 58% through lifestyle changes, with a 71% reduction in those aged 60 and older. Certified diabetes educators help patients control their diabetes and improve health status, with lifestyle changes contributing to better glycemic control and reduced complications. Prevention of serious medical complications from diabetes can be as high as 90%. Lifestyle changes, taught by certified diabetes educators, lead to better glycemic control and reduced complications from diabetes. Evidence suggests prevention rates of 90% for blindness, 85% for amputations, and 50% for heart disease and stroke with proper treatment and self-management. Over 20,000 diabetes educators in the US, mostly certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, require specific health care credentials for certification. Diabetes educators certified by the National Certification Board must meet specific professional requirements, pass an exam, and renew their credentials. They are qualified to provide diabetes self-management training under Medicare. "Certified diabetes educators recognized as Medicare providers for diabetes outpatient self-management training services." Certified diabetes educators are now recognized as Medicare providers for diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The term 'certified diabetes educator' refers to a licensed health care professional specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition, certified by a recognized body. Certified diabetes educators are professionals specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes to manage their condition. They must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Certified diabetes educators must be certified by a recognized certifying body, such as the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, which meets specific requirements set by the Secretary. The certification requirements for individuals in a specified health care profession, such as diabetes educators, include having a qualifying credential, professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training, passing a national certification examination, and renewing certification periodically. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services, including economic and geographic obstacles, availability of referrals, and qualified providers. A report on these barriers is due within one year of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on barriers for Medicare beneficiaries accessing self-management training services for diabetes. A report is due within one year. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations for outreach methods to educate physicians and the public on the benefits of diabetes self-management training. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations for outreach methods to educate primary care physicians and the public about the benefits of diabetes self-management training. A report on these recommendations is due to Congress within one year. The amendments will apply to diabetes outpatient self-management training services starting at least 6 months after the enactment of the Act.
